" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="It is possible to create a task outside of a patient record. Indeed, there might be occasions when this would be useful. For example, if we want to task someone with something that wasn’t associated to a particular patient.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="A task is similar to sending someone an e-mail
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="The ‘Task’ can be assigned to one or more colleagues but by default the ‘Task’ will be assigned to yourself as ‘Me’. This is so you can set a ‘Task’ to yourself as a ‘Reminder’ if you would like to.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="When we select ‘Staff Member’ we can scroll to see other staff members which are stored here or even to groups of people if they all need to be made aware of a ‘Task’.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Once the recipient has been selected you can type a description of the ‘Task’ in the message window and then move onto the status field below where we can indicate if the ‘Task’ has been started yet or not. A due date can also be set for the action and when finished you will need to click on the ‘OK’ button at the top of the window.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="It is important to note that the task will not be sent until we ‘save’ the patient’s record.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="If you try to ‘discard’ without sending the task you will receive a warning for there being an unsent task and you will be reminded that it hasn’t gone through yet.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="There are multiple ways that you could read your ‘Tasks’. Probably the easiest method is using the ‘Tasks’ icon on the right hand side of the homescreen that we mentioned previously.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Clicking on this will give you a breakdown in terms of the numbers of ‘Tasks’ that you have currently. Clicking on the total on the left will allow you to read the individual ‘Tasks’.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Along with the message that was sent, you will see details such as which patient is involved, the date the ‘Task’ was last updated and the currents status of the ‘Task’ (i.e. not started, started.)
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="You can add your own update to a ‘Task’ by right clicking the ‘Task’ and selecting ‘Update Task’ in the following window add some text describing your update and whether this ‘Task’ has been started and click ‘OK’. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="You may also reassign the ‘Task’ quickly by right clicking on the ‘Task’ and selecting an option from here.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Once you have done a ‘Task’ it is important that you mark it as ‘Complete’. This can be done whilst updating the ‘Task’ or by right clicking and selecting ‘change status’.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="It is important to note that any task you create about a patient (even those that are marked as ‘Completed’) will always be viewable by going into the patient record and selecting the ‘Tasks’ section in your ‘Clinical Tree’.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="This brings us to the end of this chapter and onto the summary and final assessment in the final chapter." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Chapter Twelve, Final Assessment and Summary" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="0"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="You have now reached the end of this online training. Before access is given on your smartcard you will need to complete an assessment exercise. You will be expected to gain a pass mark of 80%. If you do not achieve this, we recommend you to go back through the course to refresh your knowledge before attempting the assessment exercise again." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Congratulations, you passed the assessment, we strongly recommend you take a screenshot of this slide using the Printscreen key as evidence of the completion of this assessment" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Congratulations you have completed this course, you should now be able to:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Be familiar with the key elements of the patient record,
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Know how to access your hospital’s wards and bays,
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Understand how to access and update ‘To Do Lists’,
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Be able to perform a consultation for a patient utilising clinical templates and care plans, and
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Be able to access and update your ‘Tasks’ as well as create new ones to send to colleagues.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Chapter Five, ‘Ward View’" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When you click on the ‘Ward Icon’ from the SystmOne homescreen, firstly another window will appear where you will need to select your hospital ward. This will bring you into your relevant ward containing bays for patients appropriate for your hospital. For training purposes on our demo system I will select ‘Test Ward 1’.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="After you have made your selection another window will appear which contains all of the information needed for that particular ward and should reflect the layout of your ward. Your SystmOne homescreen will still be open in another window and can be switched between if needed." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="If you need to return to the previous ward selection window or change the ward that you are viewing, you can do so by using the ‘Select location’ button on the top left hand side of the screen. This will present you with the list of hospitals and wards again and you can reselect a different one here to change the information for a different ward. This can be useful for colleagues working on more than one ward, or looking over another for reference. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="While in Ward View’, the screen has been split into two different areas. The main left hand side of the screen displays different bays in the ward and in these each that we can see contains 4 beds. Those occupied contain information associated to the patient staying in that particular bed. The empty beds simply display as blank here, but we can scroll down the ward to view more bays and rooms.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="There are two icons which we can see at the top of the beds, the first indicates that the patient is in a bed close to the door and the second indicates that the patient is in a bed near a window." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="On the right hand side of the screen and on the top of the screen there are filters to make it easier for you to select specific patients under different categories.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The default view shows all patients but we can select a filter here, for example all patients categorised with a delayed discharge from the ward by clicking on the text label for this. Now we can see that the patients have been filtered and show just three in a filtered list. We can return back by clicking on the purple folder icon on the top bar and next to this we also have the ability to zoom in and out which you may find useful. On this top toolbar there are also further filters here such as filtering by alerts or by patients with open tasks. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Lastly, if you wanted to focus on just one of these bays on the ward, you can select one bay only by double clicking on that particular bay near the bay title to view only patients in that bay and the others will be filtered out. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="If we double click in the middle of any of the unoccupied beds on this ward we will see another window called ‘Actions and Information’. This screen displays information about the bed such as the requirement to deep clean the bed before further use. The left hand side contains buttons which perform actions such as marking the bed as clean, reserving the bed for a patient etc. This would usually be led by the ward clerk. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="We can also see that there is usually another tab called ‘Patient’ available at the top of the screen if the bed is filled but in this instance it is greyed out. We will go over this in more detail later when a patient is occupying a bed.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When we zoom in and look more closely at an occupied bed, we can see that there are icons and text which all indicate something different. The alert box at the top displays icons which indicate things about the patient, when hovering you can see these in more detail, in this instance the patient has a peanut and egg allergy among other alerts.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The patient information section containing text provides a description of this patient and when you hover shows more detail such as patient notes, name, occupational therapy assessments and more.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The ‘To Do List’ contains all of the actions assigned to the patient and their progress. When hovering over this section a long list of this patient’s ‘To Do List’ will appear and the circles which appear and scroll at the bottom indicate using a traffic system how these have developed.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Finally if the record has a red bar at the bottom as this one does it is indicating that the patient has been labelled with ‘Do Not Attempt Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (DNACPR)." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="As well as being labelled with DNACPR, there are other abbreviations and labels that can be applied to the patient bed footer. These can be added and removed by right clicking over the patient bed and selecting ‘Display’ then ‘Amend Ward View Patient Footer’ from the sub menu. This then opens another window which will allow you to make changes to the the colour label on the bed which can either be blank, red for DNACPR or black to indicate that the patient has unfortunately passed away.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Below this, we see that there is a field for adding an abbreviation to the bed footer which is used to indicate to colleagues if there is a visit by a specialist planned that day, the list contains many abbreviations such as ‘SLT’ to indicate that a speech and language specialist is due, ‘FAM’ to indicate that family are visiting and so on. These footer tools allow a quick and easy way to communicate with colleagues working with multiple patients." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="If we double click on the patient alerts area of a patient bed in a ward, a new window will open allowing us to edit or create new alerts for this patient. In this new window we can see that there is a long scrolling list of different alerts that we can set for the patient by simply ticking next to the text. This list contains a wide range of alerts such as allergies, continence, diet, fluid intake, movement, Covid 19 status and many more. We can see the icons that will be applied to the patient bed next to he text here and once new selections have been made you will apply these by selecting ‘OK’.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Chapter Six, ‘To Do Lists’" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The ‘To Do List’ can be accessed in full by double clicking on the ‘To Do List’ area on the patient bed. This will bring up another screen which contains all of the jobs, care plans and other actions associated with this patient. This screen can be seen in two parts, on the left side of the screen we have overdue jobs and this is where care plans are displayed, some of the jobs are duplicated on the right hand side of the ‘milestones’ screen. The patient notes are on the far left hand side of the screen so that we are reminded which patient we are amending. We can scroll down to see all of the items on the ‘To Do List’.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The items in the ‘Milestones’ right hand section and care plans on the left follow a ‘Red to Green’ system which is commonly used on wards. The items in red are not yet started or needing urgent attention, the items in amber are in progress but not yet finished and finally the green items are jobs which have been completed. In our demo here we can see that it isn’t a completely accurate representation of a typical ‘To Do List’ as we have lots of overdue and not yet started tasks dating all the way back to 2020. Usually a patient’s ‘To Do List’ will be more up to date and contain more of a mix of red, amber and green items which will be updated and completed regularly. ‘Red to Green’ meetings are conducted daily on wards where each patient will be discussed and the workload will be distributed among staff. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="If we wanted to amend a care plan which is only found on the left hand side of this screen, we can click on the arrow at the end of the care plan text and here we have three options. We can select ‘Complete’ to be taken through to the care plan for us to fill in for this patient. We will go over care plans in more detail later in the course, but essentially you will fill in the fields on this screen for the patient and click on ‘OK’ to return to the ‘To Do List’. We will see this updated in the ‘To Do List’ if a care plan has been completed for a patient. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="If we wanted to amend another item on a ‘To Do List’ we do so in a similar way to amending a care plan, by clicking on the arrow at the end of the text for the item which brings up another menu. Once opened we have options to mark the item as ‘In progress’ which changes it to amber or ‘complete’ which changes it to green and it is moved alongside the other completed green items. The item can be backdated on the following window if need be but it defaults to the current date and time. You also have the option to amend the notes associated with the item or we can delete the item, but this is more here for ward clerks if an item needs removing." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Chapter Seven, ‘Actions and Information’" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="We looked at ‘Actions and Information’ earlier for an empty bed, we will now look at this screen when we are selecting a bed occupied by a patient.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When we double click on the patient information section of a bed, the ‘Actions and Information’ screen will appear. This time instead of opening on the bed tab, the screen opens on the patient tab which was greyed out before and details lots of information about this patient which can also be found when hovering over a section of the bed. Here we can see information on the right about the patient such as their consultant, when they were admitted, notes and expected discharge date. Below this information we can also see a detailed look at the patient’s alerts and any ‘Reminders’ and their priority." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="On the left side of the screen here, we can see that there are lots of buttons which starts an action for the patient. The selection here will vary depending on the patient’s conditions but you should be able to find the actions you may be required to take for the patient listed here. A useful button here to remember is the ‘Retrieve Patient’ button and this will launch us into the patient’s record. As the layout of these buttons can change per patient, there is an alternative way to access these options which many users prefer which would be seen by closing this and returning to the ‘Ward View’ screen." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="All of the options we just saw in the actions and information screen can also be accessed by simply right clicking on a patient in a bed. There are some really useful options here to remember, firstly after right clicking if you hover over ‘discharge’ we can see quick options to record detail, discharge the patient and manage the discharge status when these need updating. While right clicking probably the most useful area for students and apprentices will be the ‘clinical’ option, this again duplicates the action buttons earlier and can be used to quickly amend details and record daily admission status among other options. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="We can also access clinical templates for the patient from this menu while right clicking by selecting ‘Clinical’ and clicking on ‘record assessment’. This launches another window which lists a wide variety of clinical templates we can use, we will look at these in more detail in a later chapter. As an example we will look at the general observation clinical template here and it will then launch the template with various options for us to fill in for the patient. Once we exit this it will update the patient’s record with the additional clinical template." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Another useful tool after right clicking on the patient bed is to select ‘Amend ward stay notes’ from the ‘clinical’ menu. This brings up a text box and allows you to add text which will then appear on the patient bed itself in the actions and information screen and when hovering. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Finally we can right click on the patient bed again and select the ‘Retrieve Patient’ option here which bring us into the patient record as if we were searching for this particular patient. When we are inside a patient record we will be able to view all of the patient’s recorded information and make any amendments as we saw in the ‘Clinical Tree’ chapter. When we have made our amendments and wish to exit we can select either discard to leave without making any changes or save which will save any amendment you have made here and return you to the ‘Ward View’ screen.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
